channel.title: Creating a bot
channel.description: I know the general way everyone makes bots is with Java using either Reflection or injection to hack runescape... but I was wondering today... What are some other ways to do it? I would really like to try it another way just to see what could happen, but I'm not very knowledgable with much of anything, lol. So, anyone have some suggestions, hell theories even, on different ways to hack RS?

item.title: Creating a bot
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

super_:

the medium is the medium in which it can access client state; an agent, a loader, whatever. the bot system itself should be content with any medium for accessing client state as well as any medium for being controlled (local and remote).

So the medium is basically just an abstraction layer, amd I reading that correct? and the only code that changes is the middle man?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

that’s practically what i said

Read full topic

item.title: Creating a bot
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:15, topic:348238”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=444621.msg3266688#msg3266688 date=1278906531]

the medium in which to access the bot shouldn’t change any part of the master code if you’re not shit

No bot that I know about has done anything like that since Aryan, well actually aryan renamed the client and the bot part stayed the same, so you’d have to go back to sbot 2’s updater where the updater changed the bot code every release. So that was kind of a useless statement wasn’t it?
[/quote]actually that was kind of the point, in case you didnt realize he was implicitly stating that all bots that have ever been made public suck dick

That isn’t what he stated, he said don’t use bots where the bot code has to change every time the client changes. I said that no one has written a bot like that since sbot 2, which was mid-2005, so his statement was useless. :)[/quote]actually, no, that isn’t what he was saying

he’s referring to building the actual bot system on top of the ‘medium’ layer which i assume he was referring to things like reflection, bytecode injection, graphics hacks, etc - in other words, making the ‘master code’ independent of the ‘medium’ used, an abstract system

Read full topic

item.title: Creating a bot
item.dc:creator: @Pwnaz0r Pwnaz0r
item.description:
@Pwnaz0r wrote:

If you want to do something “new”, the java bot model that are public could be improved a lot. If your willing to manipulate bytecode, the interface injection/wrapper method is just scratching the surface as to what you can do. Anyways, as far as other languages or technologies go, I believe you could write a color bot in other languages.

Read full topic

item.title: Creating a bot
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[ul][list]You could hook the openGL dll and colour entities by id, but there is a problem that you can only have one client running

EDIT - See an example here:
http://uppit.com/0yyp9owv3hiq/Interception-0.1a.zip

http://villavu.com/forum/showthread.php?t=54447

[QUOTE=silentwolf;678200]Presenting: [SIZE=“4”]interception v0.1a[/SIZE]
[SIZE=“1”](Suggestions for a cooler name welcome. As opposed to reflection, which reflects RS client variables, interception intercepts data being sent to the graphics card)[/SIZE]

This is some very rough proof of concept of code. This should not be used in a bot in it’s current form.

Feedback wanted! Tell me if it crashes, breaks or doesn’t work as expected. Tell me what (basic) features you’d like to see implemented.

[SIZE=“4”]Usage:[/SIZE]

1. Set your gfx to the following: (After chaging these settings, you need to close down RS and start it again)

24v1rp2.png740×489

Fog needs to be on! This is confirmed.

2. Install the plugins: (do this once)
[list]
[]Place ogl_plugin2.dll in your SCAR plugins folder.
[]Place opengl32.dll in “C:\Program Files\Java\jre6\bin” or equivalent.
[/list]

3. Then, in this exact order:

[LIST=1]
[]Close down SCAR and any instance of RS you have open (i.e. your browser).
[]Start up RS (normal client, not SMART, but in IE/firefox) in HD mode. Wait for login screen to appear.
[]Start up SCAR.
[]Create a SCAR script, e.g. below.
[*]Run the script! If you try and start SCAR before RS has fully loaded it will probably crash out. This will be fixed later on.
[/list]

Example SCAR script. Moves the mouse to a banker in East Varrock. Will probably work for other bankers too. IDs of each model is the number that floats above in game.
[scar]
program New;
{.include srl/srl.scar}
var
x,y: integer;
begin
SetupSRL;
if(FindModelByID(x,y, 588752808)) then
begin
MMouse(x, y, 0, 0);
Writeln(‘x=’ + IntToStr(x) + ‘, y=’ + IntToStr(y));
end else
begin
Writeln(‘Model not found.’);
end;
end.
[/scar]

FindModelByID prototype:
[scar]function FindModelByID(var x, y: integer; id: integer): boolean;[/scar]
Returns true if model with ID specified is found and false if not found. If found, x,y coords placed in x and y. Else contents of x,y should be ignored.

Finding IDs of models:
[LIST=1]
[]Press numpad 5 to enable overlays
[]Press numpad 7, 8, 9 and nine to choose different strides. Don’t worry what a stride is, this just breaks the models up into groups so it’s less cluttered on screen.
[*]If the ID of the model you want isn’t displayed, try a different stride.[/ul]

Here’s an example:

I pressed 5 to enable overlays, then pressed numpad 9 to find the ID of the bank booth (35240154) under stride 24.

[SIZE=“4”]Warning:[/SIZE] The drawing of overlays could, at least in the future, be detectable. While I doubt this would currently be detected, especially at this time, it will be good practice to only draw overlays when you’re on a character you don’t mind getting banned!

[SIZE=“3”]Bugs/features to come:[/SIZE]

[ul][]Returning coords of the centre of the model, not the first vertex
[]Running multiple clients at once
[]Finding ground and world models
[]Function to return array of all models found, instead of just one
[]Make it work without needing fog on
[]Bringing up the world map and closing it breaks interception[/ul]

[SIZE=“3”]Testers so far:[/SIZE]
Working:
nielsie95
marpis
The Man
Infantry001
Iroki
Lancelot074
r!ch!e
mormonman
J_Pizzle
Home
bbri06
Runescape Pro
The Claw

Not working:
TRiLeZ
Smarter Child
Timer - SCAR plugin - function not found

Have fun :)[/QUOTE]

Read full topic

item.title: Creating a bot
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I feel like I just answered this question not too long ago:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:2, topic:346150”]Asking a question like this is just going to get you a different answer from every person, they all have their upsides and downsides, and in the end it all boils down to opinion and what you like best and are most comfortable with. Sort of like the linux KDE vs Gnome vs Xfce argument, or the windows vs linux vs mac.

My opinion about the subject though would be to write the bot in Java, using either bytecode injection (faster) or reflection (potentially less detectable), always using only the unsigned client. Give your bot access to the code by either loading the applet like a browser would, writing it as a java agent, or attaching to the running VM. Then give it input by generating mouse and keyboard events silently but exactly how a real human giving the bot real events would look like. (you can use the event generating classes from cherokee)

Good enough answer?[/quote]

Not exactly, but close enough. You have to get the information to act on some way, and your options are limited. Basically reflection, interface/method injection, or renaming are your options. You do have other options, such as a Man In The Middle approach (proxy bot), and looking directly at the memory, but there are reasons no one currently uses those, because they are way too hard to keep updated each revision, I would call trying to do it that way a nightmare.

Your real choice comes in the way you get access to the code, which is covered in my quote.

edit: Another option I didn’t really think of before (because it’s so bad) would be to modify rt.jar, or even modify and compile your own VM for the applet to run in (using OpenJDK).

Read full topic
